name: Caesarea Maritima
shortDescription: Roman port city in Judea; home of Philip the Evangelist and Cornelius; where Paul was imprisoned; seat of Eusebius and Origen
fullDescription:
Caesarea Maritima (Caesarea by the Sea), built by Herod the Great between 25-13 BCE, was the magnificent Roman administrative capital of Judea and one of the ancient Mediterranean's most impressive port cities. Named in honor of Caesar Augustus, the city featured an artificial harbor (Sebastos), a theater, hippodrome, palace, and temple to Roma and Augustus. This engineering marvel became the setting for pivotal moments in early Christian history.

The Book of Acts identifies Caesarea as the home of Philip the Evangelist (one of the Seven Deacons, not to be confused with Philip the Apostle). After evangelizing Samaria and baptizing the Ethiopian eunuch, Philip settled in Caesarea with his four prophesying daughters (Acts 21:8-9). Here Paul stayed with Philip on his final journey to Jerusalem. The city was also home to Cornelius, the Roman centurion whose conversion marked the first Gentile baptism and the pivotal expansion of Christianity beyond Jewish boundaries (Acts 10).

Paul had extensive connections to Caesarea: he landed here after his conversion, was escorted here when Jewish opponents sought his life in Jerusalem, and was imprisoned for two years under Governors Felix and Festus before appealing to Caesar and sailing to Rome (Acts 23-26). His defense before Agrippa II and Festus‚Äî'Almost thou persuadest me to be a Christian'‚Äîoccurred in Caesarea's praetorium.

In later centuries, Caesarea became a center of Christian scholarship. Origen established a theological school and library here (c. 232 CE), and Eusebius, the 'Father of Church History,' served as bishop (c. 314-339 CE), writing his monumental Ecclesiastical History using Origen's library. The city's archaeological remains, including the famous 'Pilate Stone' discovered in 1961, continue to illuminate biblical history.

geography.location: Mediterranean coast of ancient Judea (modern Caesarea, Israel)

inhabitants.name: Philip the Evangelist
inhabitants.description: One of the Seven Deacons; settled in Caesarea with four prophesying daughters

inhabitants.name: Cornelius the Centurion
inhabitants.description: Roman centurion; first Gentile convert baptized by Peter

inhabitants.name: Paul the Apostle
inhabitants.description: Imprisoned here two years; defended faith before Felix, Festus, and Agrippa

inhabitants.name: Origen of Alexandria
inhabitants.description: Established theological school and library c. 232 CE

inhabitants.name: Eusebius of Caesarea
inhabitants.description: Bishop c. 314-339 CE; wrote Ecclesiastical History

inhabitants.name: Herod the Great
inhabitants.description: Built the city and named it for Caesar Augustus

events.name: Construction by Herod (25-13 BCE)
events.description: Herod the Great built Caesarea Maritima with its artificial harbor (Sebastos), theater, hippodrome, and temple to Roma and Augustus.

events.name: Conversion of Cornelius (c. 40 CE)
events.description: Peter baptized Cornelius, a Roman centurion, marking the first Gentile conversion and pivotal expansion of Christianity (Acts 10).

events.name: Philip Settles in Caesarea (c. 40s CE)
events.description: Philip the Evangelist settled in Caesarea with his four prophesying daughters after evangelizing Samaria and baptizing the Ethiopian eunuch (Acts 21:8-9).

events.name: Paul's Imprisonment (c. 57-59 CE)
events.description: Paul was imprisoned in Caesarea for two years under Governors Felix and Festus, defending himself before Agrippa II before appealing to Caesar (Acts 23-26).

events.name: Paul Stays with Philip (c. 57 CE)
events.description: On his final journey to Jerusalem, Paul stayed with Philip the Evangelist and his four prophesying daughters (Acts 21:8-9).

events.name: Origen Establishes School (c. 232 CE)
events.description: Origen of Alexandria moved to Caesarea and established a theological school and major library.

events.name: Eusebius Writes Church History (c. 324 CE)
events.description: Eusebius, bishop of Caesarea, wrote his Ecclesiastical History using Origen's library.

events.name: Discovery of Pilate Stone (1961)
events.description: Italian archaeologists discovered an inscription mentioning Pontius Pilate as Prefect of Judea, the only archaeological evidence of his governorship.

mythologyContexts.usage: Home of Philip the Evangelist; site of first Gentile conversion; Paul's imprisonment; center of patristic scholarship under Origen and Eusebius

textReferences.context: Philip settles in Caesarea; Cornelius's conversion; Paul's imprisonment
Major source for early church history, written in Caesarea

mythologyContexts.symbolism: Caesarea represents the crossing of boundaries: the Gentile mission began here with Cornelius's conversion, breaking the barrier between Jew and Greek. Philip the Evangelist's residence here symbolizes the movement of the Gospel from Jerusalem to the ends of the earth. Paul's imprisonment and defense before Roman authorities prefigures the Church's engagement with empire. The city's role as scholarly center (Origen, Eusebius) shows how the faith preserved and transmitted its foundational documents.
mythologyContexts.culturalSignificance: Caesarea's archaeological remains provide crucial evidence for New Testament history, including the Pilate Stone (1961), the only inscription mentioning Pontius Pilate by name. The city's theater, harbor, and aqueducts illustrate the Roman world in which early Christianity spread. Ongoing excavations continue to illuminate biblical accounts and early church development.

mythologyContexts.usage: Roman administrative capital; site of Jewish-Gentile tensions; theater of Jewish War events
names: Migdal Sharshon (ancient Hebrew name for the location)

textReferences.context: Describes Herod's construction and Jewish-Gentile conflicts

mythologyContexts.symbolism: Caesarea represented Roman power in the Jewish homeland. Herod's construction honored Caesar while providing Jews a major port. The city became a flashpoint of Jewish-Gentile tension, with conflicts here helping trigger the Jewish War (66 CE). The tension between Jewish identity and Roman rule found physical expression in this city named for the emperor.
mythologyContexts.culturalSignificance: Jewish-Gentile conflicts in Caesarea over civic rights contributed to the outbreak of the Jewish War in 66 CE. The city served as Roman headquarters for suppressing the revolt. Rabbis debated whether one could study Torah in its pagan environment. After 70 CE, the city became seat of the Roman governors who replaced the Jewish high priesthood as authority over Judea.

mythologyContexts.usage: Provincial capital; Herodian engineering marvel; symbol of Roman-Hellenistic culture in the East
mythologyContexts.symbolism: Caesarea embodied Roman civilization transplanted to the East: engineering prowess (artificial harbor), cultural institutions (theater, hippodrome), and imperial cult (temple to Roma and Augustus). The city demonstrated how client kings like Herod could advance Roman interests while maintaining local power.
mythologyContexts.culturalSignificance: Herod's construction of the harbor Sebastos (using innovative hydraulic concrete) was one of the ancient world's greatest engineering achievements. The city became a model for Roman provincial capitals, combining administrative, commercial, and entertainment functions. Its theater could seat 4,000; the hippodrome hosted chariot races for 20,000 spectators.

heroes.name: Philip the Evangelist
heroes.description: Settled in Caesarea with four prophesying daughters

places.name: Jerusalem
places.description: Paul was sent to Caesarea from Jerusalem for protection

places.name: Rome
places.description: Paul appealed to Caesar and sailed from Caesarea to Rome

places.name: Samaria
places.description: Philip evangelized Samaria before settling in Caesarea

etymology.origin: Named by Herod the Great in honor of Caesar Augustus. 'Maritima' (Latin: 'by the sea') distinguishes it from Caesarea Philippi in the north.
etymology.development: Strato's Tower (Phoenician) -> Caesarea (Herodian) -> Caesarea Palaestinae (Roman) -> Qisarya (Arabic) -> Caesarea (modern)
etymology.protoIndoEuropean: From Latin 'Caesar' (possibly from *caes- 'to cut' or Etruscan origin)

originPoint.name: Caesarea Maritima
originPoint.description: Mediterranean coastal city, midway between modern Tel Aviv and Haifa, Israel. Built on site of Phoenician Strato's Tower. Now a major archaeological park and tourist destination.

firstAttestation.description: Herod the Great began construction of Caesarea

keyMoments.significance: One of ancient world's greatest building projects completed
First Gentile baptism opens Christianity to all nations
Two years in custody; defense before governors and Agrippa
Violence in Caesarea helps spark the Jewish War
Caesarea becomes major Christian scholarly center
First archaeological evidence of Pontius Pilate
